duplicate with #2622

> @KomachiSion
> is there any other way to implement the multi Keys Sharding？
> i want to use this soon，look forward to your reply! thank you

Multi Keys Sharding without `between and ` can work.
if want to implement multi Keys Sharding with `between and `, must modify the source code.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35563513/60317282-f114cc80-99a0-11e9-9d2a-a8f0a1fa14fe.png)

Here, the sql parser parses the first null of values ​​into SQLTextExpression, causing the final SQL to become insert into pes_cs (shop_id,name) value ('null','ee')

`select tbasicupms0_.basic_up_msg_id as basic_up1_0_, tbasicupms0_.basic_up_msg_no as basic_up2_0_, tbasicupms0_.cust_sender_ic as cust_sen3_0_, tbasicupms0_.data_source as data_sou4_0_, tbasicupms0_.data_type as data_typ5_0_, tbasicupms0_.forward_number as forward_6_0_, tbasicupms0_.hex_sms as hex_sms7_0_, tbasicupms0_.is_del as is_del8_0_, tbasicupms0_.palt_receive_ic as palt_rec9_0_, tbasicupms0_.process_status as process10_0_, tbasicupms0_.process_time as process11_0_, tbasicupms0_.project_id as project12_0_, tbasicupms0_.receipt_time as receipt13_0_ from t_basic_up_msg_201901_1 tbasicupms0_ where tbasicupms0_.receipt_time='2019-01-01 00:04:10.0'`

All index has been dropped.(exclude PRIMARY)

Now it's normal after I created another index and then droppd it.
It's really puzzling！！！
I’m looking for the root cause.(I don‘t know if it is related to the version of MySQL
)

I am thinking for a while. I guess, the samples are too few. and the test results are not stable.
You can increase the querys to 5 million, maybe you will find something.

I‘ll try it later.
I can confirm that the index cause the problem. Because the improvement is obvious now.
Thank you for your time.

Hello I hava a new question.

**How should we create index after using sharding-jdbc？**

The sharding key is named receipt_time **(type :datetime).**

I just create an index like `ALTER TABLE t_basic_up_msg ADD INDEX idx_upmsg_receiptTime(receipt_time);`

`ALTER TABLE t_basic_up_msg_201901_1 ADD INDEX idx_upmsg011_receiptTime(RECEIPT_TIME);
ALTER TABLE t_basic_up_msg_201901_2 ADD INDEX idx_upmsg012_receiptTime(RECEIPT_TIME);
.......
ALTER TABLE t_basic_up_msg_201912_1 ADD INDEX idx_upmsg121_receiptTime(RECEIPT_TIME);
ALTER TABLE t_basic_up_msg_201912_2 ADD INDEX idx_upmsg122_receiptTime(RECEIPT_TIME);`

and then
query become more slowly(It's obvious，slower 3 times).

my sql:
`select basic_up_msg_id , basic_up_msg_no ,cust_sender_ic,data_source, data_type, forward_number, hex_sms,is_del,palt_receive_ic, process_status, process_time , project_id , receipt_time from t_basic_up_msg where receipt_time='2019-01-01 00:04:10.0'`



Any suggestion?thanks.
You can open a new issue for the new question.

query sql： above

sharding： 2s      nosharding：20s

    after add index
   sharding： 700ms    nosharding：250ms

Sharding-jdbc needs fixed time to parse/optimize..../merge SQL.
But the amount of data is not large enough.
The response time is too  short after add index.
This cause we need more time to query after using sharding-jdbc.



Or the use of index is not correct.


Do you have any other ideas? or any suggestions?

I'm increasing the amount of data.But it needs time.

and it supposed to be ok with mybatis-plus.

Sharding-jdbc is on JDBC layer, MyBatis is ORM layer, Sharding-jdbc should not care about how to use   it with ORM.
Please provide show.sql log, exception stack trace or let ORM layer to resolve it.

duplicate with #2628

My phenomenon is that using mybatis-plus XML to write SQL can not route to the real table, did not go to the sharding algorithm. Mybatis -plus packaged crud, can successfully route to the real table.

this is show ShardingSphere sql
```
ShardingSphere-SQL - Logic SQL: SELECT * FROM user_tag WHERE ax_uid = ?
ShardingSphere-SQL - SQLStatement: SelectStatement(super=DQLStatement(super=AbstractSQLStatement(type=DQL, tables=Tables(tables=[Table(name=user_tag, alias=Optional.absent())]), routeConditions=Conditions(orCondition=OrCondition(andConditions=[])), encryptConditions=Conditions(orCondition=OrCondition(andConditions=[])), sqlTokens=[TableToken(tableName=user_tag, quoteCharacter=NONE, schemaNameLength=0)], parametersIndex=1, logicSQL=SELECT * FROM user_tag WHERE ax_uid = ?)), containStar=true, firstSelectItemStartIndex=7, selectListStopIndex=7, groupByLastIndex=0, items=[StarSelectItem(owner=Optional.absent())], groupByItems=[], orderByItems=[], limit=null, subqueryStatement=null, subqueryStatements=[], subqueryConditions=[])
ShardingSphere-SQL - Actual SQL: ds0 ::: SELECT * FROM user_tag WHERE ax_uid = ? ::: [3]
```

Previous fixes may cause performance issues when actual nodes with large number.
So we will consider new solution for this issue.

FYI: https://shardingsphere.apache.org/document/current/en/features/orchestration/config-center/
**For English only**, other languages will not accept.

As we know, MySQL does not have built-in Boolean type. However, it uses TINYINT(1) instead. To make it more convenient, MySQL provides BOOLEAN or BOOL as the synonym of TINYINT(1) . In MySQL, zero is considered as false, and non-zero value is considered as true.

Convert BIT to Boolean is abuse, BIT is for binary value, not boolean value. I suggest that you change the column type from BIT to TINYINT.
FYI: https://shardingsphere.apache.org/document/current/en/manual/

```
dataSources:
  ds_0: !!com.zaxxer.hikari.HikariDataSource
    driverClassName: com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
    jdbcUrl: 'jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/sharding_test?useSSL=false&allowMultiQueries=true&useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=UTF-8'
    username: root
    password: 123456
    maximumPoolSize: 2

shardingRule:
  props:
    sql.show: true
  defaultDataSourceName: ds_0
  tables:
    t_order_archive:
      actualDataNodes: ds_0.t_order_2019_0${1..6}
      tableStrategy:
        standard:
          shardingColumn: f_created_at
          rangeAlgorithmClassName: com.test.sharding.OrderRangeShardingAlgorithm
          preciseAlgorithmClassName: com.test.sharding.OrderPreciseShardingAlgorithm
```
This is how I configure it and it works well.But there's a problem, if I published my project in 2019-06-30.By 2019-07-01, because t_order_2019_07 data node was not configured,so I have to reconfigure the actualDataNodes and publish the project again. Can I config the actualDataNodes dynamically without re-publishing the project.

You may execute DDL first, and then update configuration

ShardingSphere design as: If there is write operation in the same thread and database connection, all the following read operations are from the master database to ensure data consistency.

So if you using ShardingSphere, you can not query from slave after updated.

FYI: https://shardingsphere.apache.org/document/current/en/features/read-write-split/core-features/
Has it been solved? @weweibuy

> Convert BIT to Boolean is abuse, BIT is for binary value, not boolean value. I suggest that you change the column type from BIT to TINYINT.

change to TINYINT(1) also throws java.lang.ClassCastException: [B cannot be cast to java.lang.Boolean
change to TINYINT(2) throws org.apache.shardingsphere.core.exception.ShardingException: Unsupported data type:boolean

Get it.
Can you help to test whether this change works?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24643893/60572344-ffe7ee80-9da7-11e9-8d4a-2257478d21c1.png)

> ShardingSphere design as: If there is write operation in the same thread and database connection, all the following read operations are from the master database to ensure data consistency.
> 
> So if you using ShardingSphere, you can not query from slave after updated.
> 
> FYI: https://shardingsphere.apache.org/document/current/en/features/read-write-split/core-features/

I know this is for data consistency.
sometimes i need switch datasource to slave in transaction, can i do this from some api?
@terrymanu

No, the API is unnecessary for most scenario. 
As a product manager, I prefer do not add this API, because do not consider about data consistency is incorrect behaviour.

If some special scenario you needed, you may fork and do it by yourself.
If there's no problem, you can submit a pull request instead of the previous one. This change will not lead to side effect.

Compilation failure.
```java
case "boolean":
    return 0 != number.longValue()
```
it only fixes the case of tinyint(2).

Sorry, codes should like this:

```
case "boolean":
    return 0 != number.byteValue()
```
Don't need no support tinyint(2), only support tinyint(1).

It was restored because it only works with mysql and sql server and does not support postgresql. In postgresql, 116 is true and the other numbers are false.
I think there are two ways to solve this problem:
1. QueryResultUtil#getValueByColumnType() adds a convertType class param, which is converted directly to the correct field type here.
2. Provide different conversion methods according to different databases.

But both ways will make a lot of changes.
